name: Interpretive Governance
purpose: Define a machine-first governance standard that constrains interpretation, decision-making, and agentic outputs in probabilistic systems by enforcing explicit statement typing, traceability, legitimate refusal conditions, and (as of v0.2.0) memory-aware invariants for stateful systems.

applies_to: machine interpretation of content and artifacts
generation of statements and decisions in probabilistic systems
agentic tool-use when governed by explicit policies
stateful memory persistence, consolidation, and controlled forgetting
does_not_apply_to: claims of factual correctness without traceable sources
guarantees of safety or harm prevention
closed, unverifiable memory systems without auditable logs

core_principles: Explicit statement typing is mandatory for governed outputs.
Traceability is required for high-confidence claims.
Legitimate refusal is required when evidence is missing or constraints fail.
For stateful systems, memory artifacts must be typed, versioned, traceable, and auditable over time.

artifact_types.description: A typed, versioned, traceable unit of persisted memory (statement or consolidation).
An append-only event log capturing memory lifecycle changes (create, consolidate, invalidate).

profiles.name: memory-aware
profiles.description: If the system is stateful (persists memory), memory constraints apply in addition to base L0â€“L4 requirements.

conformance_break_triggers: model weights or model version changed without re-audit
embedding/index rebuilt without integrity recalculation and without append-only logs
memory consolidation rules changed without versioning and audit trails
memory logs lost, truncated, or made unverifiable
normative source hierarchy changed without traceable policy updates
